div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,452] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, March 23, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express to Switerland, Paris and London, leaving venice at 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieate every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste- Vienna- Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cario will find special through carriages and language-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 14 March, 1, 11,and 25 April; 1, 9, and 22 May; 6 June, 4 p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria 5 and 19 March.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 March, 13 April, 13 November, 13 December (Winter Lane).

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: DES ENFANTS, LE DÉLICE!
div.p: C'est l'Emulsion Scott, si douce au palais que les bébés la prennent par gourmandise et si légère à l'estomac qu'ils la digèrent sans difficulté! Et quel bonheur aussi pour vous, chères mamans, d'avoir la réconfortante certitude de pouvoir, avec cette salutaire
EMULSION SCOTT,
le meilleur remède qui soit au monde, guérir toutes les affections dont serait affligé votre enfant :
DÉPÉRISSEMENT. ECZÉMA, RACHITISME. ACCIDENTS DE DENTITION. TOUX ET RHUME!
Exigez donc l'Emulsion Scott puisqu'elle est seule capable de vous assurer une guérison radicale!
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.
Exigez toujours l'Emulsion avec cette marque : "le Pécheur", marque du procédé Scott !

div.head: Direction der Disconto-Gesellschaft
div.p: Berlin - Bremen - Frankfurt a. M. - London.
Capital (fully paid-up) M 170 000 000
Reserve Fund ... M 57 600 000
Represented at Hamburg by the Norddeutsche Bank in Hamburg.
The bank transacts general banking business of every description and acts as representative of the following foreign banks:
Brasilianische Bank für Deutschland of Hamburg, with branches at Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo, Santos and Porto Alegre.
Bank für Chile und Deutschland of Hamburg, with branches at Valparaiso, Santiago, Concepcion, Temuco, Antofagasta, La Paz and Oruro.
Ernesto Tornquist & Co. Buenos Aires.
Deutsch- Asiatische Bank of Shanghai, with branohes at Berlin, Calcutta, Hankow, Hongkong, Kobe, Peking, Tientsin, Tsinanfu, Tsingtau, Yokohama.
Banca Generala Romana of Bakarest, with branches at Braila, Crajeva and an Agency at Constantza.
Kreditna Banka (Banque de Credit) at Sofia
Damara- und Namaqua Handels-Gesellschaft, Banking Department, at Swakopmund, Windhuk and Lüderitzbucht (South West Africa).
S M S Lorelay,
The German despatch boat Loroely (Captain voh Kroeigk) arrived at Alexandria on Satur- day from Constantinople on a cruise in the Levant.
American Deserters.
Quite a number of sailors have deserted from the American Squadron now at Alexandria. There is a reward of £2 for anyone securing a deserter and getting him aboard.
Playing with Fire.
'A native girl of ten was playing with matches when her dress caught fire and caused her serious burns. She was taken to hospital a precarious condition.
Lord Cromer's Report.
We are informed that Lord Cromer's Report for the past year will probably not be in the hands of the public much before the end of next month.
ftew Khedivial Hotel.
Owing to the hall to be given to-morrow evening in. aid of the Fonidlings' Home, persons wishing to dine at the New Khedivial Hotel are requested to order their tables beforehand.
Karr el-Aly.

Prince Ahmed Pacha Kamal has, says a native contemporary, recently sold his share in the Kasar l-Aly estate at Cairo for the sum of L.E 750,000. The share of Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim io the same estate was previously sold for LE. 180,000.
English Printing In Egypt.

Messrs. Wsterlow Bros, and Latyton, Ltd., the well-known London printer, having considerably extended their buisness in Alexandria, have enlarged their factory at Menayer and are opening offices in the Boulevard de Ram'eh. They are also sequiring an office in Cairo.
Alexandria Constanxa Line.

The general arrangements of the new Roumanian service between Alexandria and Constanta have been settled by M. Boeresco, the Inspector Gentral of the Roumanian Maritime Service, who has recently been paying a visit to Alexandria in connection with the work of organi- sation of the line. He has now returned to Conatanza.

div.head: No. 3 Palace.
div.p: No. 3 Palace, the Alexandria residence of the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, situated at Hadra, which was purchased ten yean ago by Ghati Mnkhtar Pacha from H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly for th» torn of L.E. 6,500, and which latterly became the property of tho Turkish Government, has been gifted by the Saltan to Mnkhtar Paoha. His Excellency has, as a mark of gratitude, presented a sum of LE. 10,000 for the Hedjaz Railway. The present value of No. 3 Palace it estimated at L.E. 120,000.
Jewish Choral. Society.

A charming conoert wte given last night by the Jewish Choral Society of Alexandria in the ball-room of the New Khedivial Hotel. The society, which has only been in existence tor a few years, has become one of the most efficient choral societies in Egypt. The members of the soeiety sang four pieces with great success. Miss G Capozzo and Maedamas Calistti and Bounici were much applauded. One of the most delightful pieces rendered was Saint Sacčus’ trio for the violon, 'cello and piano from Samson and Delilah, given by Professors Borghesi and Lanzoni. The Governor of Alexandria and a large and fashionable audience were present
Ramleh's Home of Rest,

The following is an extract from a letter to the “Sphinx" from Mrs. Freeman, who is so much interested in philanthropic work both at home and here in Egypt: - "Many of your roaders may be glad to hear of an undertaking just started in Ramleh, near Alexandria,whioh will conduce to the rest and comfort of many weary workers all over Egypt, who are unable to go home or to Europe for their much needed rest. Four years ago Miss Van Sommer bought a piece of groaod overlooking the and built there a Home of Rest for English missionaries end workers. Till then there had been nothing of the sort for the English in Egypt, and I think that many of our country people who have spent their winter in Egypt; might like to send a little help to further this effort for the comfort and rest of these who work all the year round in the heat of the day for the good of the country and the furtherance of Christianity. Any gift may be sent to Miss Van Sommer, Fair Haven Account, Anglo- Egyptian Bank, Alexandria."
Spend your Holidays at Mena.
The management of Mena Hoose Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [ Advt.]

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd' d hui à midi et demie)
La oote continue à fléchir en prévision de la prochaine liquidation de fin du mois.
La National Bank toube à 27 7/4l'ancienne, i 27 U nonvelle, la Delta Light 112 8/16, le Comptoir’k 7 1/8, l'UrbaiDe I 65/16, la Ramleh ‘Railway I 6 7/8. etc.
En revanohe la Delta Land eat an pen pine farms 18 7/16, les B tates b 2 1/82, let Markets 124/9, les Nungovioh V 17.
Quant aux affaires elles ont A A glsirremées ear toote la ligne et n'oot eo aooone importance.

div.head: AMERICAN SQUADRON.
div.p: BANQUET AT ABDEBN PALACE

H H. the Khedive gave a banquet at Abdeen Palaco on Saturday evening in hononr of Rear-Admiral Sigsbee and the officers of the Amerioan Squad on now in Alexandria harboor. The Khedive presided and the guests numbered forty, among them being Rear-Admiral Sigsbee, the Hon. L. M. Iddings, Ameriosn Diplomatic Agent and Consul General,and Mrs. Iddings, Mr. and Mrs. Grew, Judge Tack, Mr. and Mrs. Leigh Hunt, Mr. and Mrs. Bacon, Capt. Nazro. Commander Cutler, Commander Smith, Lt Commander Holmes, Surgeon Odell, Asst. Surgeon Belknap, Lieut. Trant, Paymaster Heap, Lieuts. McCauley, Landis, Lackey end Lewis; Ensigns Andrews and Loomis; Midship man Wickerham, and Midshipman James. His Highness received his guests in a moat hospitable manner, and the dinner was of the most sumptuous description. His Highness's private band discoursed a selection of music during the evening, the programme including several southern negro' melodies, which were remarkably well rendered and most enthusiastically received.
After dinner the naval officers attended the Savoy small dance.
Admiral Sigsbee and his staff lunched with Consul General and Mrs. Iddings yesterday, returning to Alexardria in the afternoon.
This evening Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield is giving a dinner to the Admiral and officers at the New Khedivial Hotel.
Admiral Sigsbee will give a large dinner party on board the Brooklyn in the middle of the week.
Two of tho cruisers of the equadron, the Galveston and tho Chattanooga, leave today for the Par Eut.

div.head: AUSTRO-HUNGARIAN SQUADRON.
div.p: The Austro-Hungarian Squadron will probably remain at Alexandria until tho 11th April.

The ball which is to be given next week on board the Habsburg and the St. George is to be a magnificent affair. These two ironclads are to be drawn op alongside each other in order to form one series of ballrooms, reception rooms, and buffets for the guests.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive gave audience on Friday to Mgr. Porpbyros, Bishop of Sinai, Prince Kamel el Din, Mr. Gibson, and tbe Rev. Mr. Kaufmann.
On Saturday the Khedive gave audience to tho Ministers, Yacoub Pacha Artin, Mr. Edouard Naville, and Mr. Grubb.
On Saturday evening the banqnet in honour of Admiral Sigsbee and the officers of tbe Amerioan Squadron took place at Abdeen Palace.

div.head: THE NEW ‘‘ADVISER."
div.p: Dr. Dunlop’s appointment as Adviser to the Ministry of Pablic Instruction arouses excited and furious comments on the part of the Anglophobe vernacular Press, who consider it as a rejoinder to the recent strikes in the Government schools.

div.head: A CANARD.
div.p: Some of our Cairo confréres have recently published a statement lo the effect that a consession had been granted to a syndicate for the erection of telephone lines to connect Port Said with several towns of the interior. The news is manifestly incorrect since the telephone system already existing in Port Said and Zagazig (as well as Suez) belongs to the Telephone Company of Egypt, and should such lines as the local papers mention be erected by the Government Telegraph Department the company in question would have the preference, so that no syndicate is likely to be given a new conceusion until its refusal by the existing Telephone Company, which, we understand, is not the case.

div.head: ANOTHER EGYPTIAN MINING
div.p: ISSUE. Mr. Tyudale White, who presided at the meeting of the Egyptian Mines Exploration last week, said that the company had steadily opened up what the board believed would prove a rich mining area. They had proved the value of the Um Ros Mine, which had passed from the status of a prospect to that of a crushing mine. The company had, however, suffered, as all pioneers suffered, from the heavy expenses incidental to the eatablishment of a now industry, end the business had increased so rapidly that it would reqnire new capital. They had spent about £40 000 in five years, and the subsidiary companies £47,000 more. Generally they were slowly advancing from the exploratory stage to that of valuable gold mines. Though living through bad times, as far as markets were concerned, the result of the developments had left little to be desired, and if times were normal no doubt they would be able to dispose of the company's properties on terms which would show handsome profits. Mining in Egypt as likely to produce satisfactory profits as in any other part of the world, and be confidently recommended them to take shares in them company which he hoped would be shortly brought before them. The company had unitsued shares and other means of raising money for its own purposes, but the heavy expenditure on the three mines must be undertaken by a separate company.

div.head: FRONTIER DISPUTE.
div.p: SITUATION AT TABAH UNCHANGED
REPORT QF THREATENED
BOMBARDMENT DENIED.
( Gazette's Special Service. )
London, Monday.

The ‘ Daily Telegraph’s" correspondent at Constantinople reports that the situation at Tabah is unchanged. The British Embassy at Constantinople, on behalf of Egypt, has requested the Turks to leave. Any further action will emanate from the Foreign Office and Egypt.
London, Monday.
This morning new concerning the Akaba incident is without foundation. (Reuter)

We are officially informed that the statements contained in the Reuter's telegram from London and the Havas telegram from Constantinople, to be found in another colomn, are entirely inoorrect so far as regards the bombardment of Akaba.
We are authorised to state that the negotiations between the Egyptian Government and the Sublime Ottoman Porte are still in progress, and that the reply of the Porte is now being awaited.
(From our Correspondent).
Sues, Saturday.
H.H.S. Aida sailed for Akaba yesterday with stores and despatches for H.M.S. Diana.
H.M.S Hogue arrived at Suez from the South, end entered the Canal yesterday.

div.head: AMERICAN STOCKS & SHARES.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
New York. Monday.
ARRANGEMENTS AT SUEZ.
(From our Correspondents).
Suez, Sunday.
H.M.S. Renown sailed from Aden yesterday afternoon, and is due to arrive at Suez next Wednesday evening.

T. R. H. the Prince and Princess of Wales will land on Thursday forenoon at the Dock station, where preparations are now being made for their reception. H.H. the Khedive's train will be in readiness at the docks to convey the distinguished visitors to Cairo. All trains will be stopped en route in order that the special train may be able to have a run to Cairo.

div.head: THB PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: (From our Correspondent. )
Suez, Sunday.
The Khodivial mail liner Fayoum arrived at Suez this morning from Tor with a considerable number of Egyptian pilgrims.

div.head: THB SUCRERIES.
div.p: It it reported, thoogh unofficially confirmed, that the Parquet will prosecute the conseil d'administarion of the Sucreries Company.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GOUVERNORAT.
div.p: H E. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky ceased to be Governor of Alexandria yesterday, and will leave for Cairo to take up his new post on Friday next His successor, H.E. Mustapha Pacha Ibady, will not leave Suez for Alexandria until after the arrival of the Prince and Princess of Wales at Suez.

div.head: PENNY POSTAGE.
div.p: The reduction of postage to 6 millièmes will be extended to letters exchanged between Egypt, including the Sudan and the following countries, with effect from the 1st April next:
Sierra Leone, Jamaica. Somaliland. Gold Coast, Lagos, Barbados, Hong Kong, Ceylon, Falkland Islands, St. Helen, and Mauritius.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL.
div.p: Sulkeley (near Alexandria)
BAMLEH'S FASHIONABLE HOTEL. Patronized by the elite.
Full Pensien from P.T. 50 a day. Vlaiters from Caire alight at Sidi-Gaher station.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

div.head: National ’Rank of Egypt.
div.p: REPORT OF DIRECTORS

The report of the directors presented to the sixth ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the National Bank of Egypt, held in Cairo on Saturday last, shows that during the year ouding tbo 31st December, 1905, a grow profit was raised of £408.902.10.8, of which 81.724.2.10, derived from special investments, are exceptional profits. Deducting rebate of interest, £27,418.14.9, and the current expenses, £84,906 5.9, there remains a net profit of £296,577 9.9. The following distribution is laid down by the statutes of the Bank : 4 % to the capital, or 8s. per share, £100,000. 10 % of the net profit to the reserve fund, £29,657.15. 10% to the directors, £16,691.19 6, leaving a balance of £150,227.15 8, to which must be added the balance carried forward last year. £80.417.81, making a total of £180,675.3.4. The directors recommend the payment of a dividend of an additional 8s. per share, which will absorb £100,000 and leave £80,675.8.4. They farther recommend that a sum of £50,000, to be taken from the exceptional profits referred to above, be carried to a reserve fund to be employed specially for equalising future dividends and that £30,675.8.4 be carried forward to profit and loss new account. Each share will thus be entitled to 16s, equivalent to 8 per cent. on the capital.
The following is the text of the chairman's speech at the meeting of shareholders:—

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Mou liner Meneptheh wiled hence on Saturday kvening for Liverpool vid Malta with ~v>seneer», mails s^d general oargo, indoding 34 bales cotton adBu 583 bags onion*. The Mom liner rabe sailed yesterday aftarooon for Nioolaief in ballast. The Moss liner Marie arrived here on Saturday afternoon from Barry with a cargo of ooal.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

Three Sailings a-Week.

Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: CAIRO FLOWER SHOW.
div.p: OPENED BY KHEDIVE.
FAVOURED BY FINE WEATHER.

The Spring Show given by the Kbelivial Horticultural Society was opened on Saturday afternoon at three o'clock by H.H. the Khedive, who arrived punctually at that hour. Perfect weather favoured the occasion, and though some of tha exhibits showed signs of weariness before the afternoon area over, the genial warmth was much appreciated by the visitors. Lord and Lady Cromer arrived early on the scane, the latter looking very well in a gown of light fawn cloth outlined with a narrow trimming of blue and black, and among others ready to recieve his Highness were the Sirdar, Sir Reginald Wiogata, and Lady Wingate, Mr. Machell, Lady Velda Machall, in a pretty gown of thio black lace over pale blue, with touches of pink in the lace vest, M. and Mme Villebois, the latter in dark blue, Crookahank Pacha, Mrs. Crook shank, wearing cream with heavy lace insertions, Capt. the Hon. C. James and Mrs James, Mr. Iddinga and his young daughter in white, Mr. and Mrs. Foaden. the latter wearing dark blue, and Lord Edward Cecil.
The Khedive's Arrival.

His Highness who was met at the enterance by Dr. Keatings, made the tour of the building and the tents in the company of Lady Cromer and appeared mnch interested in all the various exhibits of plants, flowers, and vegetables; and by 3.30 the rest of the world were admitted to follow in his footsteps. Mr. and Mrs. George Royle were there, the latter in a long white surge coat and skirt, and with them came Mrs. Maclean in a dark blue suit, Mr. and Mrs. Allen Joseph cams early, as did Mr. and Mrs. Satow, Mrs. Satow wearing a pretty soft shade of blue with deep points of heavy lace upon the bodice. Mrs. Madden,who was accompanied by her children, was in blue mus'in, and Miss Phillips, wearing heliotrope, was with Dr. and Mrs Phillips. Lady Willcocks was with friends, and Sir Horace and Lady Pinching were dutifully doing the rounds. Lady Pinehing wearing a costume of pale fawn with narrow bands of paune of a deeper shade, and a vary pretty Sèvre blue hat Miss Gordon Soott was in cream voile with lace corsage and her wide-spreading hat was of russet coloured chiffon and lace with a big bunch of white plumes. The Miles de Villaboii, who were among those present at tha arrival of the Effeodina, were in soft silks of palest amber and had on hats of Tascan straw flower bedecked, and both Mrs. Carton de Wiart and Miss James wire in dainty grey toilettes Sir Malcolm and Lady Mellwraith were present, the latter in cream with blue sash and a big blue veil floating around her hat and Mrs. Graham looked very well in a soft shade of green voile with fine lace about the shoulders. Col. and Mrs. Matchett Bay were oresent as were also Mrs. Matchett Innes, Mrs. Reid. Mrs. Knight, Boghos Pacha Nubar and Mile Nuba, M. and Mme. Maskens. Bonuteau Bay, and many others.

flowers scattered over them. Mrs. Maclean won also the first prize for her dejsuner table, which was effeotively decorated with daffodils and gypeophilia is silver bowl and vases, and Mrs. Royle was awarded second prize for her table upon which appeared a very handsome array of scarlet poppies and green grasses in silver vases. There were many who admired Mrs H. Garney Sheppard's table, which were decorated with nutrients end gysophilia, and Mrs. Chakourhad arranged a very effaotive design in white and yellow may. Mr. Stamm bad contributed a vary handsome table hors concours with a high centre piece filled with long branches of pink roses trails ol roses connected with green ribbon lying on the cloth.
Cut Flowers.

There were two first prises for the beat arrangement of out flowers in vases. Mrs. Carton de Wiart won hers with every handsome high vase filled with masses of bankeia roses, and Miss Reid had the most gorgeous collection of La Prance roses in a bowl. The second prize went to Mrs H. Wilson, who had filled a low vase with a handsome group of pink and yellow roses, and Mrs. Sheppard was awarded an honourable mention for the most artistic arrangement of wild flowers from Mariout in a tall, slander silver vase.

Mra Carton do Wiart likewise won the first priM for tha beet d too rated basket of thwers, with a beautiful green basket filled with deep orimaoe rorev. The eeoond prin in this class went to Misi Crewe, who had fi'led ber basket with roMi and may. Much credit is al*o due to tbe baskets decorated by various native gardeners and other*, some of which were esoeedingiy elegant.
Model Garden.

Native ingenuity was also responsible for the wonderful model garden and house which was exhibited in the centre of the building. The little house and lodges were of wood, painted white and gold, and many lighted lamps decorated hot boildings and garden walls, wonderful artificial flowers appeared in the flower beds, and a life sized canary kept guard by the front door, and a gaily colored paved pathway meandered at great length from gate to gate.

The vegetables, fruits, etc., ware exhibited in an adjoining teat, but whatever their intrinsic value their artiatio merits do not for special mention in these columns. A seductive array of jams, preserved fruits, end syrups of all kinds claimed the attention of the domestically inclined, and the good house-wife found much to hanker after in the other exhibits, But to the general ran of visitors the excellent tea-tent hard bye held irreristable attractions.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the pasengers who left by the Austrian mail on Saturday were Prince von Liohtchendtein, Princess Radiivill, Counters Oynhausen and daughter, Conotoss Hawerdin, Baron Bruckmann, Count and Countess de Kuenberg, Capt. Grogan, Capt. Powell, etc.
Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, accompanied by Beneducci Bey, paid a visit this morning to the commandant of the German despatch-boat Lorely.

The death is announced at Omdurman, of El Miralai El-Nur Bay Mohamed, so well known in the recent history of the Sudan. El Nur Bey, it will be remembered, was commandant of the troops at Senuar, which he valiantly defended when the Mahdi's influence was rising and eclipsing that the Egyptian Government. His name will always remain engraved in the history of the Sudan as that of a loyal and brave soldier.
Judge and Mrs. Alaton gave a dinner of 14 covers at Mens House Hotel yesterday evening.
The names of Col. Maberly, D.S.O., and od Major Owen were omitted from the list of the hosts in our account of the recent Bachelors' Ball.

Mr. and Mrs. Lamplough are leaving Cario for England on the 31st, and Mr. Lamplough takes back with him many an inspiration for his exhibition of sketches to be held in London during the early summer. It is much to be regretted that Mr. and Mrs. Lamplough have finished their season here under very sad circumstances. It was only a few days ago that they received a cable from home announcing the sad fact of the death of their baby daughter whom they had left with relatives less than three months ago. The Symmpathu of all their friends is with them in their bereavement.

The following Army officers have been granted leave of absence, on private affairs:- Lieut. B.A.P. Schreiber, 20th Hussars (adjt. M.M.P.), Major C. A. Wilding, Capt. S.J. Somerville, Capt. R. Blackett, Lieut. W.E. Rothwell 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers; Capt. and Brevet Major H.M. Finch and 2nd Lieut. J.R. Robertson, 2nd Royal Barks. Regt; Rev. F.I. Anderson, C.F. The later has permission to travel in Italy, Switzerland, France, and Great Britain.
A marriage has been arranged between Mr. John Schilizzi and Miss Helen Lounghis, both of this city.
The marriage of Mr. John H. Burton to Miss Mary Smith will take on Wednesday April 18.
